item.title: Cuphead Deluxe Edition Art Book Is Over 60% Off At Amazon
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

If you're looking for a nice gift for a fan of Studio MDHR's popular run-and-gun game Cuphead, you should check out Amazon's deals on The Art of Cuphead: The Delicious Last Course. Published last fall by Dark Horse, the beautiful slipcased Deluxe Edition is on sale for only $36 (was $100) at Amazon. Alternatively, you can get the standard hardcover edition for $19.27 (was $40). Take a closer look at both editions below.

These are just a few of the official Cuphead books available now; you can check out comic books, novels for young readers, and even picture books on this Amazon store page we created. We also collected all of the officially licensed Cuphead plushies available for reasonable prices, including the ultra-soft Club Mocchi-Mocchi 15-inch plush, which is a great pillow to rest against while flipping through Cuphead artwork.

The Art of Cuphead: The Delicious Last Course Deluxe Edition

$36 (was $100)

The Deluxe Edition comes with a mint green foil-stamped slipcase and a foldout portfolio with three acetate cells. The content in the book matches the standard edition, but the Deluxe Edition has a ribbon bookmark, too.

This lavish set matches the Deluxe Edition for the base game's art book. Fair warning: The Art of Cuphead Deluxe Edition has only been available to purchase from third-party sellers for years at this point--it truly was "limited," unlike some video game art books.

It's surprising that the Deluxe Edition is still in stock one year after its release, but the $64 discount certainly feels like Amazon is clearing out the last of its inventory.

The Art of Cuphead: The Delicious Last Course

$19.27 (was $40)

The Art of Cuphead: The Delicious Last Course is a 272-page oversized hardcover focused exclusively on Cuphead's brilliant 2022 DLC (Delicious Last Course). The book takes fans on a frame-by-frame journey through the expansion's seven bosses and The King's Leap challenge arena. Delicious Last Course also introduced Ms. Chalice as a playable character and numerous new NPCs who will likely be featured in this art book.

If you've played Cuphead, you know the level of detail on display in each of the game's inventive boss battles. The DLC actually has as many frames of animation as the base game, despite it only comprising about 25% of the full Cuphead experience.

Along with frame-by-frame animation of the bosses you can find in The Delicious Last Course, this book contains early concept art as well as unused ideas.

Just like Dark Horse's art book covering the base game--The Art of Cuphead is on sale for $27.69 (was $50)--this is a must-own book for fans of Studio MDHR's brilliant run-and-gun / boss rush games.

The Art of The Cuphead Show

$30.88 (was $50)

For even more Cuphead fun, check out Dark Horse's art book detailing the creation of Netflix's awesome animated series that ran for three seasons.

The 256-page book includes exclusive production art, character designs, animatics, and commentary from the writers and designers responsible for adapting Studio MDHR's cartoon-inspired game into an actual cartoon.

item.title: Skyblivion Is Delayed To 2026, But It Already Looks Very Good
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The dream of Skyblivion goes back over a decade as a team of fans came together to use The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim's engine to fully recreate and re-imagine Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion as a modern RPG. At the beginning of 2023, the team set a 2025 premiere for Skyblivion. However, that's no longer the plan and Skyblivion has been pushed to next year. The good news is that the latest dev video shows off how much has been finished and what remains to be done.

Skyblivion lead Rebelzize narrates the video as he offers a guide to where things stand. According to Rebelzize, most of the work has already been done and over 70 volunteer contributors are still hard at work trying to get the ambitious mod across the finish line.

When this project was started, The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion was far out of date. Earlier this year, Bethesda released Oblivion Remastered, which could have taken the wind out of this team's project. Instead, Rebelzize and others praised the remaster as a "win-win" for the community. In recognition for their work, Bethesda gave copies of Oblivion Remastered to the entire Skyblivion mod team.

However, it hasn't been entirely harmonious for team Skyblivion. Earlier this year, a former member of the team spoke out against efforts to rush the mod out before it's ready. As impressive as Skyblivion is, no one is getting paid for it, and the ex-team member is against the crunch-time mindset that was making things more difficult.

For now, it looks like Skyblivion is worth the wait. Although Bethesda does offer some support for mods on consoles, it will only be available on PC. Skyblivion will also require players to own both Elder Scrolls 5 and Elder Scrolls 4 in order to work.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/skyblivion-is-delayed-to-2026-but-it-already-looks-very-good/1100-6536682/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Call Of Duty Mobile Season 11 Adds A Cool Crossover You Won't Find In Black Ops 7
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty Mobile is celebrating the game's sixth anniversary with plenty of new content. While Black Ops 7 is sticking to thematically appropriate operator skins, Season 11 of Call of Duty Mobile includes a major crossover with Street Fighter, which allows players to transform into the popular fighting characters and use their iconic fighting moves. This new season also adds a DMZ extraction mode, new loadout items to unlock, and special events.

Season 11 start date details

Season 11 starts on December 11 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET. This new season includes a brand-new battle pass with both free and premium items.

Battle pass details

The main highlights of the free battle-pass tiers are the SO-14 marksman rifle and Wheelson-HS scorestreak. There are also weapon blueprints, skins, and other cosmetics available to unlock for free.

For the premium tiers, the battle pass offers the "Mauy Claus" Santa operator skin for Ajax and the "Iron Kata" skin for Sparrowhawk. Holiday-themed weapon blueprints are included for the Krig 6 assault rifle, CBR4 submachine gun, and the season's new SO-14 marksman rifle.

New events

New events will allow players to earn Street Fighter-themed rewards and other cosmetics from Secret Caches. Each Secret Cache offers a random reward, and they are available to earn through many different events throughout the season, with four caches available to claim daily through login rewards and various events.

Season 11 also includes sixth anniversary-themed rewards across two separate anniversary events. These rewards include items, such as weapon blueprints, calling cards, weapon charms, and more.

Additionally, holiday events will also arrive later in the season for players to earn festive cosmetics.

Street Fighter LTMs

While Activision has decided to shy away from wacky skins for Black Ops 7, the publisher continues to introduce major IP crossovers into Call of Duty Mobile. Season 11 is themed around Street Fighter, and this brings new challenges and limited-time game modes inspired by the characters of the iconic fighting game.

For multiplayer, Shoryu and Hadoken is a limited-time mode available across a select map pool. Scorestreaks are disabled in this mode, and operators enter the match equipped with only the Prizefighter gloves melee weapon and increased jump height, which is meant to reflect the martial style of Street Fighter.

Players melee and build up a rage meter until they earn enough to transform into either Hidora Kai for Ryu or Shigenori for Akuma. Ryu's move set offers his classic Hadoken projectile ability and his powerful wave motion fist attack, Shinku Hadoken. Akuma's combat style uses the Shoryuken rising uppercut and the Shun Goku Satsu attack. The first player to land enough eliminations is the winner.

Battle royale also has a limited-time Street Fighter mode. This lets players find holograms of four different Street Fighter characters on the mode's Isolated map. Interacting with the holograms for Ryu, Akuma, Chun-Li, and Cammy will let the player acquire their unique abilities and activate special attacks to use during the match.

DMZ Recon mode

Call of Duty Mobile adds a new extraction mode inspired by Modern Warfare 2's DMZ called DMZ Recon. This introduces a brand-new map called Serpent Island, which is a large-scale map composed of multiple zones, including points of interest inspired by fan-favorite Call of Duty maps. Players will need to drop in, loot up, and extract to keep their gear.

Building 21 from MW2 DMZ also returns. This is an entirely indoor map spread out over three floors, offering a faster pace and more close-quarters action compared to the larger Serpent Island map.

Additionally, DMZ Recon features new challenges and over 20 more camos to unlock for Call of Duty mobile.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Game With Amazing Premise Has Been Canceled
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Legendary game designer and programmer Ron Gilbert (Monkey Island) has revealed that one of his exciting-sounding upcoming projects has been canceled due in part to investors not coming to the table to fund the project.

Speaking to Ars Technica, Gilbert said this game had a vision of being a "large, open-world-type RPG" in the vein of The Legend of Zelda. Gilbert worked alongside two other people--an artist and a designer--for about a year on the project before Gilbert realized it was not going to happen.

"I just [didn't] have the money or the time to build a big open-world game like that," he said. "You know, it's either a passion project you spent 10 years on, or you just need a bunch of money to be able to hire people and resources."

Gilbert previously described his new project as "classic Zelda meets Diablo meets Thimbleweed Park," and a lot of people were excited to find out what that might look like. Now it's not happening.

"Horrible" publishing deals

Gilbert said he pitched the project to people in the industry but discovered that "deals that publishers were offering were just horrible."

The kind of game Gilbert envisioned "isn't the big, hot item" so potential publishers didn't invest, he said. "The amount of money they're willing to put up and the deals they were offering just made absolutely no sense to me to go do this," he explained.

Gilbert funded 2017's Thimbleweed Park on Kickstarter, bringing in more than $600,000 USD. Gilbert also took private investment to complete the project.

The industry veteran observed that publishers today can be "very analytics-driven" and have devised their own formulas to "try to figure out how much money they could make." The result of this, Gilbert observed, is that publishers take on less risk, and in turn, games that do get made often look the same.

"You end up [getting] a whole lot of games that look exactly the same as last year’s games, because that makes some money," he said. "When we were starting out, we couldn't do that because we didn't know what made this money ... I think that's why I really enjoy the indie game market because it's kind of free of a lot of that stuff that big publishers bring to it, and there's a lot more creativity and you know, strangeness, and bizarreness."

Gilbert's latest game is Death by Scrolling, an action game that was released at the end of October this year. Before that, he partnered with Devolver for Return to Monkey Island.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/game-with-amazing-premise-has-been-canceled/1100-6536678/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

item.title: Metroid Prime 4: Beyond Players, Be Sure To Do This Before Entering Endgame
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Getting 100% completion in a Metroid game--and metroidvania titles in general--is a satisfying achievement that's part of the genre's appeal. However, in Metroid Prime 4: Beyond, there is unfortunately a way to pigeonhole yourself where collecting everything needed isn't possible. Now, the game will warn you about a point of no return, but it's still easy to make a regrettable decision. That's why GameSpot's reviewer for the first-person adventure, Steve Watts, advises players to make a copy of their main save in another save slot before entering the endgame.

Watts detailed the "confusing choice" that Nintendo and developer Retro Studios made in his Metroid Prime 4 review. "When I was ready to proceed to the endgame, I got the usual warnings about a point of no return, but I had figured I could always load an older save to go back and do more exploring to pick up power-ups that I missed," Watts wrote. "But the auto-save now has me locked into the final area with no such apparent option, and my regular save slot--the one that activates when Samus steps into a save station--has been overwritten with a Mission Complete, so loading it prompts me to start a new game."

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

Now Playing: Metroid Prime 4 Beyond Review

The main menu does allow you to make a copy of a game in a different slot. If you want to proceed to the endgame to see how the story concludes, while allowing freedom to go back and explore, make sure that you either make a copy of your save or opt not to overwrite with a Mission Complete save. That said, there's always the possibility that Nintendo and Retro address this confusing issue with a future update for the Switch and Switch 2 game.

Metroid Prime 4 launches tomorrow, December 4. The game features a new voice actor for Samus Aran with Erin Yvette replacing previous Metroid Prime mainstay Jennifer Hale. In addition, Krystle Martin provides the motion capture for the bounty hunter. For more, check out GameSpot's Metroid Prime 4 buying guide.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Clair Obscur Cast Wants TGA To Have More Awards For Actors
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 has enjoyed an exceptional year, becoming the most-nominated game in the history of The Game Awards. Its cast--Ben Starr, Charlie Cox, and Jennifer English among them--earned major recognition in the show's performance categories, helping cement the game as one of the year's standout achievements. But even while celebrating this success, the cast has been discussing ways the awards could grow, especially when it comes to recognizing the full range of performance work that brings modern games to life.

In an interview with Video Games Chronicle, cast members English, Shayla Nyx, Devora Wilde, and Aliona Baranova shared their hope that The Game Awards will eventually expand its performance categories. They explained that, while the nominations are an honor, the current categories overlook many essential performers.

"If I may, can I put my petition forward for why we need to have a motion capture category?" Baranova said. "It's been decades of actors going in, doing the mocap, and then someone else's voice is popped on top, and those mocap performers just disappear. I forgot that. Nobody knows about them.” Baranova, who worked as a motion capture director on Baldur's Gate 3, noted that this issue has persisted for years.

She added that recognition could also help audiences better understand the craft. "The audience doesn't know enough about this because there's not enough attention on it," she continued. "If we had an award category for mocap specifically, then studios would be encouraged to release that behind-the-scenes footage because people are desperate for it. Studios keep that a bit quiet because it gives away details on how they made the game."

Actor Charlie Cox echoed the sentiment last month, saying that although he's "thrilled" about his nomination, credit for his role in Expedition 33 must be shared with motion capture performer Maxence Carzole.

"It needs to happen," Baranova added. "I posted about it online the other day, and some people were questioning like, "How would we do it?'. I don't know, they can figure it out. We need to do it because there are these fantastic mocap performances going on."

Devora Wilde agreed, saying, "Yes, I was actually surprised about that for The Game Awards. But I think that's always been the case, hasn't it? It's just been 'performance in a game'."

The Game Awards will stream live from the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles on December 11, and in case you didn't know, you can also vote in the awards.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/clair-obscur-cast-wants-tga-to-have-more-awards-for-actors/1100-6536676/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
